Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Porous Metal-Organic Framework Materials for Industrial Gas Storage and Separation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gases are important raw materials for a large number of chemical transformations/productions, and are used as routine energy resources for both industrial enterprise and our diary life. Because of their unique state, special handling and transportation are necessary for their routine usage. Gas cylinders, typically under high pressures, are essential for gas storage. Although the gases are compressed under high pressure into the gas cylinders, the gas storage capacity by such traditional methods are typically not high. Furthermore, the high pressure might also have some safety concerns. Materials with higher gas storage capabilities can not only increase the gas storage amount within fixed cylinder spaces, but also reduce the storage pressure for gas storage and, thus, improve safety concerns. This project explores the market potential of porous metal-organic framework (MOF) materials for industrial gas storage and separation, particularly methane and acetylene storage, and separation of acetylene/ethylene. Through the implementation of new materials for the high capacity storage of natural gas and acetylene for the future vehicles, it reduces the United States' heavy dependence on the gasoline energy resource and diminishes the environmental side effect of carbon dioxide emission from the combustion of high carbon hydrocarbons.

Porous MOF materials are very promising adsorbents which can be filled into gas cylinders to significantly enhance the gas storage capacities. The tunable pores and functional sites within porous MOFs have also enabled these porous materials to be very useful for gas separations. This team will conduct customer discovery during the 7-week I-Corps program to assess the industrial customers' real needs in terms of gas storage and separation, and the target market size. Following completion of the I-Corps curriculum, the team will decide whether or not to establish a start-up company and to continue its commercialization efforts through SBIR and/or STTR funding.

Institution.Name: University of Texas at San Antonio
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT SAN ANTONIO, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Texas at San Antonio

POR.DRECONTENT:
With this support, a team of Dr. Huimin Wen (EL), Jeff Q Xu (M) and Dr. Banglin Chen (PI) has been able to attend two NSF I-Corp workshops held at LA (April 4-6; May 16-17), participate in over 100 interviews and attend several national and international conferences to comprehensively evaluate the market needs for our materials and technologies for the acetylene storage.  Our studies have shown that there is no commercialized materials/technology which can provide high purity acetylene storage. Our materials and technologies can meet this important need and then facilitate the wide usage of acetylene as the raw chemical for chemical transformations and production of new pharmaceutical compounds. The team members have learned a lot on the commercialization process, how to make a judgement on the feasibility to commercialize, how to have a right judgment on the market needs and to do cost analysis.This project has also provided the great training opportunity for the postdoctoral fellow to prepare her future career.

Porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are indeed very promising materials for high purity acetylene storage. With the commercialization of more porous metal-organic frameworks at a reasonable cost, it will be feasible to implement some MOF materials for their industrial applications on gas storage and separations.


Last Modified: 02/02/2017
Modified by: Banglin Chen
